 2020
 2019 and 2018 were comprised of the following:




			
			

			

			
			

			

			
			

			

			



			

			
			


			
			
			


			
			
			
			
			



			

			
			
			
			
			
			


			
			
			
			
			


			
			
			
			
			
			
			
			
			
			
			
			
			



			

			
			


			
			
			


			
			
			
			
			












 2020 the Board suspended the Company&#8217;s first quarter cash dividend payment to preserve cash and provide additional flexibility in the current environment as a result of the economic impact of COVID-19. Furthermore
 the Board has suspended future quarterly dividends until the significant uncertainty of the current public health crisis and global economic climate has passed and the Board determines that resumption of dividend payments is in the best interest of the Company and its stockholders.




 we have experienced business disruptions resulting from efforts to contain the rapid spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19)
 including the vast mandated self-quarantines and closures of non-essential business throughout the United States and internationally. Nearly all stores have been directly and negatively impacted by public health measures taken in response to COVID-19
 with nearly all locations experiencing reduced operations as a result of
 among other things
 modified business hours and store and mall closures. As a result
 franchisees and licensees are not ordering products for their stores in line with forecasted amounts. This trend has negatively impacted
 and is expected to continue to negatively impact
 among other things
 factory sales
 retail sales and royalty and marketing fees.


 our foremost priority is the safety and well-being of our employees
 customers
 franchisees and communities. In addition to our already stringent practices for the quality and safety of our confections
 we are diligently following health and safety guidance issued by the World Health Organization
 the Centers for Disease Control and state and local governmental agencies. COVID-19 has had an unprecedented impact on our industry as containment measures continue to escalate. Numerous countries
 states and local governments have effected ordinances to protect the public through social distancing
 which has caused
 and we expect will continue to cause
 a significant decrease in
 among other things
 retail traffic and factory sales as a result
 retail sales and royalty and marketing fees. With that said
 Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory products remain available for sale online. Our current focus is on supporting our franchisees and licensees during this challenging time and driving growth in our online sales
 especially in light of our ecommerce licensing agreement with Edible Arrangements&#174;
 LLC (&#8220;Edible&#8221;)
 as discussed below
 while also sensibly managing costs. The number of our and our franchisee&#8217;s stores remaining open may change frequently and significantly due to the ever-changing nature of the outbreak.
















 INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES



 management is taking all necessary and appropriate action to maximize our liquidity as we navigate the current landscape. These actions include significantly reducing our operating expenses and production volume to reflect reduced sales volumes as well as the elimination of all non-essential spending and capital expenditures. Further
 in an abundance of caution and to maintain ample financial flexibility
 we have drawn down the full amount under our line of credit and we have received a loan under the Paycheck Protection Program (the &#8220;PPP&#8221;). The receipt of funds under the PPP has allowed us to avoid workforce reduction measures amidst a steep decline in revenue and production volume. While we believe we have sufficient liquidity with our current cash position
 we will continue to monitor and evaluate all financing alternatives as necessary as these unprecedented events evolve. For more information
 please see Item 1A &#8220;Risk Factors&#8212;The Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Pandemic Has
 and May Continue to
 Materially and Adversely Affect our Sales
 Earnings
 Financial Condition and Liquidity.&#8221;


 the Company
 Management and the Board may take additional actions as a result of current events related to COVID-19. Continued or prolonged disruption to the economy may result in
 among other things: an increase in expense associated with obsolete inventory
 an increase in bad debt expense
 expense associated with the impairment of long-lived assets and intangible assets
 an increase in store closures
 a decrease in new store openings.




 2020 (the first quarter of FY 2021) and for FY 2021. We are unable to reasonably estimate the extent of these decreases. The events
 as described above
 have had a significant impact on our domestic franchisees
 domestic and international licensees and specialty markets customers (collectively &#8220;Customers&#8221;). Our ability to realize the full value of our assets depends on the ability of our customers to recover from these events and our business to resume normal operations. Among other financial impacts these events may significantly impair our ability to sell inventory on-hand
 collect receivables and realize the value of our tangible and intangible assets. We continue to monitor the situation closely and may implement further measures to provide additional financial flexibility as we work to protect our cash position and liquidity. We have determined that the events described above did not exist at the balance sheet date and have concluded that they are nonrecognized subsequent events.&nbsp; As a result of this determination no amounts were recognized as of February 29
 2020 related to these subsequent events.




 2020
 the Company provided notice to the lender to draw down on the line of credit in an amount equal to $3.4 million (the full amount of the $5.0 million line of credit
 subject to the borrowing base of 50% of eligible accounts receivable plus 50% of eligible inventories). On March 16
 2020 the interest rate for borrowings under the line of credit was 3.06%
 which represents the one-month LIBOR rate plus 2.25%. The outstanding principal balance under the line of credit will be due and payable in full on September 30
 2021. The Company elected to borrow such amounts to ensure it maintains ample financial flexibility in light of the spread of COVID-19 and the closures and/or modified hours
 either voluntarily or as a result of governmental orders or quarantines
 of the retail locations of the Company and its franchisees.




 2020
 Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory
 Inc. and U-Swirl International
 Inc. (collectively the &#8220;Company&#8221;) entered into Loan Agreements and Promissory Notes (collectively the &#8220;SBA Loans&#8221;) with 1st SOURCE BANK pursuant to the Paycheck Protection Program (the &#8220;PPP&#8221;) under the recently enacted Coronavirus Aid
 Relief
 and Economic Security Act (&#8220;CARES Act&#8221;) administered by the U.S. Small Business Administration. The Company received total proceeds of $1.5 million from the SBA Loans. The SBA Loans are scheduled to mature on April 14 and April 20
 2022 and have a 1.00% interest rate and are subject to the terms and conditions applicable to loans administered by the U.S. Small Business Administration under the CARES Act. The SBA Loans may be prepaid by the Company at any time prior to maturity with no prepayment penalties. The SBA Loans contain customary events of default relating to
 among other things
 payment defaults and breaches of representations and warranties. Subject to certain conditions
 the SBA Loans may be forgiven in whole or in part by applying for forgiveness pursuant to the CARES Act and the PPP. The amount of loan proceeds eligible for forgiveness is based on a formula based on a number of factors
 including the amount of loan proceeds used by the Company during the eight-week period after the loan origination for certain purposes
 including payroll costs
 interest on certain mortgage obligations
 rent payments on certain leases
 and certain qualified utility payments
 provided that
 among other things
 at least 75% of the loan amount is used for eligible payroll costs
 the employer maintaining or rehiring employees and maintaining salaries at certain levels. In accordance with the requirements of the CARES Act and the PPP
 the Company intends to use the proceeds from the SBA Loans primarily for payroll costs. No assurance can be given that the Company will be granted forgiveness of the SBA Loans in whole or in part.

























Because of their inherent limitations
 disclosure controls and procedures and internal control over financial reporting (collectively
 &#8220;Control Systems&#8221;) may not prevent or detect all failures or misstatements of the type sought to be avoided by Control Systems. Also
 projections of any evaluation of the effectiveness of the Company&#8217;s Control Systems to future periods are subject to the risk that such controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions
 or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. Management
 including the Company&#8217;s Chief Executive Officer (the &#8220;CEO&#8221;) and Chief Financial Officer (the &#8220;CFO&#8221;)
 does not expect that the Company&#8217;s Control Systems will prevent all errors or all fraud. A Control System
 no matter how well conceived and operated
 can provide only reasonable
 not absolute
 assurance that the objectives of the Control System are met. Further
 the design of a Control System must reflect the fact that there are resource constraints
 and the benefits of controls must be considered relative to their costs. Because of the inherent limitations in all Control Systems
 no evaluation can provide absolute assurance that all control issues and instances of fraud
 if any
 within the Company have been detected. These reports by management
 including the CEO and CFO
 on the effectiveness of the Company&#8217;s Control Systems express only reasonable assurance of the conclusions reached.

 &#8212; The Company maintains disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act)
 that are designed to ensure that material information relating to the Company is made known to the officers who certify the Company&#8217;s financial reports and to other members of senior management and the Board of Directors. These disclosure controls and procedures are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the Company&#8217;s reports that are filed or submitted under the Exchange Act
 are recorded
 processed
 summarized
 and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC&#8217;s rules and forms. Disclosure controls and procedures include
 without limitation
 controls and procedures designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the reports that the Company files or submits under the Exchange Act is accumulated and communicated to our management
 including our principal executive and principal financial officer
 or persons performing similar functions
 as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.


 under the supervision and with the participation of the CEO and CFO
 has conducted an evaluation (pursuant to Rule 13a-15(b) of the Exchange Act)
 as of February 29
 2020
 of the Company&#8217;s disclosure controls and procedures. Based on that evaluation
 the CEO and CFO have concluded that the Company&#8217;s disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of February 29
 2020.

 &#8212; Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act). The Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed under supervision of the Company&#8217;s principal executive officer and principal financial officer to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and preparation of the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. Management
 with the participation of the CEO and CFO
 has evaluated the effectiveness
 as of February 29
 2020
 of the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting. In making this evaluation
 management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in its publication Internal Control-Integrated Framework (2013). Based on that evaluation
 management has concluded that the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of February 29
 2020.

 &#8212;There were no changes in the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the quarter ended February 29
 2020 that have materially affected
 or are reasonably likely to materially affect
 the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting.

 and the Company does &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; charge any service fees. While the Company&amp;#x2019;s franchisees continue to honor all gift cards presented for payment
 the Company &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;determine the likelihood of redemption to be remote for certain cards due to long periods of inactivity. The Company has historically accumulated gift card liabilities and has &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; recognized breakage associated with the gift card liability. The adoption of ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2014&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;09
&lt;/div&gt; &amp;#x201c;REVENUE FROM CONTRACTS WITH CUSTOMERS&amp;#x201d; (&amp;#x201c;ASC &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;606&amp;#x201d;&lt;/div&gt;) during FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2019&lt;/div&gt; requires the use of the &amp;#x201c;proportionate&amp;#x201d; method for recognizing breakage
 which the Company has &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; historically utilized. Upon adoption of ASC &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;606&lt;/div&gt; the Company began recognizing breakage from gift cards when the gift card is redeemed by the customer or the Company determines the likelihood of the gift card being redeemed by the customer is remote (&amp;#x201c;gift card breakage&amp;#x201d;). The determination of the gift card breakage rate is based upon Company-specific historical redemption patterns. Accrued gift card liability was &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$609
842&lt;/div&gt; and &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$742

 and the credit quality of
 the financial institutions with which it invests. As of the balance sheet date
 and periodically throughout the year
 the Company has maintained balances in various operating accounts in excess of federally insured limits. This amount was approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$4.3&lt;/div&gt; million at &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29

 the Company extends credit to customers
 primarily franchisees that satisfy pre-defined credit criteria. The Company believes that it has limited concentration of credit risk primarily because its receivables are secured by the assets of the franchisees to which the Company ordinarily extends credit
 including
 but &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; limited to
 their franchise rights and inventories. An allowance for doubtful accounts is determined through analysis of the aging of accounts receivable
 assessments of collectability based on historical trends
 and an evaluation of the impact of current and projected economic conditions. The process by which the Company performs its analysis is conducted on a customer by customer
 or franchisee by franchisee
 basis and takes into account
 among other relevant factors
 sales history
 outstanding receivables
 customer financial strength
 as well as customer specific and geographic market factors relevant to projected performance. The Company monitors the collectability of its accounts receivable on an ongoing basis by assessing the credit worthiness of its customers and evaluating the impact of reasonably likely changes in economic conditions that &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;impact credit risks. Estimates with regard to the collectability of accounts receivable are reasonably likely to change in the future. At &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/div&gt; the Company had &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$450
215&lt;/div&gt; of notes receivable outstanding and an allowance for doubtful accounts of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$0&lt;/div&gt; associated with these notes
 compared to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$391
831&lt;/div&gt; of notes receivable outstanding and an allowance for doubtful accounts of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$0&lt;/div&gt; at &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28
 2019. &lt;/div&gt;The notes require monthly payments and bear interest rates ranging from &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;4.5%&lt;/div&gt; to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;6%.&lt;/div&gt; The notes mature through &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; November 2023 &lt;/div&gt;and approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$293
000&lt;/div&gt; of notes receivable are secured by the assets financed. We &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;experience the failure of our wholesale customers
 including our franchisees
 to whom we extend credit to pay amounts owed to us on time
 or at all

 which is adjusted for obsolete
 damaged and excess inventories to the lower of cost or net realizable value based on actual differences. The inventory value is determined through analysis of items held in inventory
 and
 if the recorded value is higher than the market value
 the Company records an expense to reduce inventory to its actual market value. The process by which the Company performs its analysis is conducted on an item by item basis and takes into account
 among other relevant factors
 market value
 sales history and future sales potential. Cost is determined using the &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;first&lt;/div&gt;-in

 which range from &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;five&lt;/div&gt; to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;thirty-nine&lt;/div&gt; years. Leasehold improvements are amortized on the straight-line method over the lives of the respective leases or the service lives of the improvements

 including identifiable intangible assets
 whenever events or changes indicate the carrying amount of such assets &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; be recoverable. The Company&amp;#x2019;s policy is to review the recoverability of all assets
 at a minimum

 using current enacted income tax rates and regulations. These differences will result in taxable income or deductions in future years when the reported amount of the asset or liability is recovered or settled
 respectively. Considerable judgment is required in determining when these events &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;occur and whether recovery of an asset
 including the utilization of a net operating loss or other carryforward prior to its expiration
 is more likely than &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not.&lt;/div&gt; Due to historical U-Swirl losses
 prior to FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt; the Company established a full valuation allowance on the Company&amp;#x2019;s deferred tax assets. During FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt; the Company took possession of the outstanding equity in U-Swirl. As a result of the Company&amp;#x2019;s ownership increasing to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;100%
&lt;/div&gt; the Company began filing consolidated income tax returns in FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2017.&lt;/div&gt; Because of this change


 and the Company does &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; charge any service fees. While the Company&amp;#x2019;s franchisees continue to honor all gift cards presented for payment
 the Company &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;determine the likelihood of redemption to be remote for certain cards due to long periods of inactivity. The adoption of ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2014&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;09
&lt;/div&gt; &amp;#x201c;REVENUE FROM CONTRACTS WITH CUSTOMERS&amp;#x201d; (&amp;#x201c;ASC &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;606&amp;#x201d;&lt;/div&gt;) during FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2019&lt;/div&gt; requires the use of the &amp;#x201c;proportionate&amp;#x201d; method for recognizing breakage
 which the Company has &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; historically utilized. Upon adoption of ASC &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;606&lt;/div&gt; the Company began recognizing breakage from gift cards when the gift card is redeemed by the customer or the Company determines the likelihood of the gift card being redeemed by the customer is remote (&amp;#x201c;gift card breakage&amp;#x201d;). The determination of the gift card breakage rate is based upon Company-specific historical redemption patterns.  &lt;/div&gt;the SEC adopted amendments to certain disclosure requirements in Securities Act Release &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;No.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;33&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;10532
&lt;/div&gt; Disclosure Update and Simplification. These amendments eliminate
 modify
 or integrate into other SEC requirements certain disclosure rules. Among the amendments is the requirement to present an analysis of changes in stockholders&amp;#x2019; equity in the interim financial statements included in Quarterly Reports on Form &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;10&lt;/div&gt;-Q. The analysis
 which can be presented as a footnote or separate statement
 is required for the current and comparative quarter and year-to-date interim periods. The amendments are effective for all filings made on or after &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; November 5
 2018. &lt;/div&gt;The Company adopted these amendments in its Quarterly Report on Form &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;10&lt;/div&gt;-Q for the quarter ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; May 31

 &lt;/div&gt;the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&amp;#x201c;FASB&amp;#x201d;) issued Accounting Standards Update (&amp;#x201c;ASU&amp;#x201d;) &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;13
&lt;/div&gt; Financial Instruments - Credit Losses (Topic &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;326&lt;/div&gt;): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments. ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;13&lt;/div&gt; significantly changes the impairment model for most financial assets and certain other instruments. ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;13&lt;/div&gt; will require immediate recognition of estimated credit losses expected to occur over the remaining life of many financial assets
 which will generally result in earlier recognition of allowances for credit losses on loans and other financial instruments. ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;13&lt;/div&gt; is effective for the Company's fiscal year beginning &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; March 1

 &lt;/div&gt;the FASB issued ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;02
&lt;/div&gt; Leases (Topic &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;842&lt;/div&gt;)
 which requires the recognition of lease assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet by lessees for those leases currently classified as operating leases under ASC &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;840&lt;/div&gt; &amp;#x201c;Leases.&amp;#x201d; These amendments also require qualitative disclosures along with specific quantitative disclosures. The Company adopted ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;02&lt;/div&gt; as of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; March 1
 2019
 &lt;/div&gt;using the modified retrospective method. This method allows the new standard to be applied retrospectively through a cumulative catch-up adjustment recognized upon adoption. As a result
 comparative information in the Company&amp;#x2019;s financial statements has &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; been restated and continues to be reported under the accounting standards in effect for those periods. The Company recorded a Right of Use Asset and Lease Liability on the Consolidated Balance Sheet of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$3.3&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; million upon adoption. The impact of the new standard did &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; affect the Company&amp;#x2019;s cash flows or results of operations. The lease liability reflects the present value of the Company&amp;#x2019;s estimated future minimum lease payments over the lease term
 which includes options that are likely to be exercised

&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; increased from the year ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28
 2019
 &lt;/div&gt;primarily as a result of an increase in state income taxes. During FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2018&lt;/div&gt; the effective rate was higher than in FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; and FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2019&lt;/div&gt; as a result of the revaluation of deferred tax assets and liabilities to the lower enacted U.S. corporate tax rate of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;21%&lt;/div&gt; under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act recognized during the year ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28
 2018. &lt;/div&gt;The revaluation of deferred tax assets and liabilities resulted in income tax expense of approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$421
000&lt;/div&gt; recognized in consideration of the lower enacted rate for the year ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28

 the Company is &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;no&lt;/div&gt; longer subject to U.S. federal and state tax examinations in its major tax jurisdictions for periods before FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2014.&lt;/div&gt; The Company&amp;#x2019;s federal income tax returns have been examined for the years ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28 &lt;/div&gt;or &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2017
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016

 in the appropriate tax jurisdictions
 in future years to obtain benefit from the reversal of net deductible temporary differences. The amount of deferred tax assets considered realizable is subject to adjustment in future periods if estimates of future taxable income are changed. Management believes that
 with the exception of the deferred tax asset related to restructuring charges
 it is more likely than &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; that RMCF will realize the benefits of its deferred tax assets as of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29

 based on the technical merits of the position. The Company measures the tax benefits recognized in the consolidated financial statements from such a position based on the largest benefit that has a greater than &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;50%&lt;/div&gt; likelihood of being realized upon ultimate resolution. The application of income tax law is inherently complex. As such
 the Company is required to make judgments regarding income tax exposures. Interpretations of and guidance surrounding income tax law and regulations change over time and &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;result in changes to the Company's judgments which can materially affect amounts recognized in the balance sheets and statements of operations. The result of the assessment of the Company's tax positions did &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; have an impact on the consolidated financial statements for the years ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28 &lt;/div&gt;or &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; or &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2019.&lt;/div&gt; The Company does &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; have any significant unrecognized tax benefits and does &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; anticipate a significant increase or decrease in unrecognized tax benefits within the next &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;twelve&lt;/div&gt; months. Amounts are recognized for income tax related interest and penalties as a component of general and administrative expense in the statement of income and are immaterial for years ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28 &lt;/div&gt;or &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29

&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016
&lt;/div&gt; the Company foreclosed on the outstanding equity of U-Swirl and U-Swirl was consolidated for income tax purposes. SWRL
 along with U-Swirl had historically filed its own consolidated federal income tax return and reported its own Federal net operating loss carry forward. As of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28
 2015
 &lt;/div&gt;SWRL had recorded a full valuation allowance related to the realization of its deferred income tax assets. As of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016

 deductibility of SWRL&amp;#x2019;s and U-Swirl&amp;#x2019;s Federal net operating loss carryovers &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;be subject to annual limitation in the event of a change in control. The Company has performed a preliminary evaluation as to whether a change in control has taken place
 and have concluded that there was a change of control with respect to the net operating losses of U-Swirl when the Company acquired its controlling ownership interest in &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; January 2013 &lt;/div&gt;and again in &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 2016 &lt;/div&gt;when the Company foreclosed on the stock of U-Swirl. The initial limitations will continue to limit deductibility of SWRL&amp;#x2019;s and U-Swirl&amp;#x2019;s net operating loss carryovers

 limited by section &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;382
&lt;/div&gt; to be approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$1
634
000&lt;/div&gt; with a resulting deferred tax asset of approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$401

  
  
  
  

 using current enacted income tax rates and regulations. These differences will result in taxable income or deductions in future years when the reported amount of the asset or liability is recovered or settled

 as a practical expedient

 renewal options are considered reasonably assured of being exercised if the sales performance of the location remains strong. Therefore
 the &amp;#x2018;Right of Use Asset&amp;#x2019; and &amp;#x2018;Lease Liability&amp;#x2019; include an assumption on renewal options that have &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; yet been exercised by the Company
 and are &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; currently a future obligation. The Company has separated non-lease components from lease components in the recognition of the &amp;#x2018;Right of Use Asset&amp;#x2019; and &amp;#x2018;Lease Liability&amp;#x2019; except in instances where such costs were &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; practical to separate. To the extent that occupancy costs
 such as site maintenance
 are included in the &amp;#x2018;Right of Use Asset&amp;#x2019; and &amp;#x2018;Lease Liability
&amp;#x2019; the impact is immaterial. For franchised locations
 the related occupancy costs including property taxes
 insurance and site maintenance are generally required to be paid by the franchisees as part of the franchise arrangement. In addition
 the Company is the lessee under non-store related leases such as storage facilities and trucking equipment. For leases where the implicit rate is &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; readily determinable
 the Company uses an incremental borrowing rate to calculate the lease liability that represents an estimate of the interest rate the Company would incur to borrow on a collateralized basis over the term of a lease. The weighted average discount rate used for operating leases was &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;3.4%&lt;/div&gt; as of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29

 collateralized by substantially all of the Company&amp;#x2019;s assets with the exception of the Company&amp;#x2019;s retail store assets. Draws &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;be made under the line at &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;50%&lt;/div&gt; of eligible accounts receivable plus &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;50%&lt;/div&gt; of eligible inventories. &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$5.0&lt;/div&gt; million was available for borrowings under the line of credit
 subject to borrowing base limitations. Additionally

Note &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19&lt;/div&gt; contains information regarding the Company&amp;#x2019;s line of credit use subsequent to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29

The Company made its &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;first&lt;/div&gt; draw of approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$6.4&lt;/div&gt; million on the Wells Fargo Loan on &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; January 16

 2014. &lt;/div&gt;Interest on the Wells Fargo Loan was at a fixed rate of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;3.75%&lt;/div&gt; and the maturity date was &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; January 15

&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; will be realized at their full value
 or if any revenue will be received from FTD in the future. During FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/div&gt; the Company recognized an estimated loss of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$230

&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020








&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; compared to revenue of approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$3.1&lt;/div&gt; million or &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;9%&lt;/div&gt; of our total revenues during the year ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

 &lt;/div&gt;the SEC adopted amendments to certain disclosure requirements in Securities Act Release &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;No.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;33&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;10532
&lt;/div&gt; Disclosure Update and Simplification. These amendments eliminate
 modify
 or integrate into other SEC requirements certain disclosure rules. Among the amendments is the requirement to present an analysis of changes in stockholders&amp;#x2019; equity in the interim financial statements included in Quarterly Reports on Form &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;10&lt;/div&gt;-Q. The analysis
 which can be presented as a footnote or separate statement
 is required for the current and comparative quarter and year-to-date interim periods. The amendments are effective for all filings made on or after &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; November 5
 2018. &lt;/div&gt;The Company adopted these amendments in its Quarterly Report on Form &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;10&lt;/div&gt;-Q for the quarter ended &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; May 31

 &lt;/div&gt;the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&amp;#x201c;FASB&amp;#x201d;) issued Accounting Standards Update (&amp;#x201c;ASU&amp;#x201d;) &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;13
&lt;/div&gt; Financial Instruments - Credit Losses (Topic &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;326&lt;/div&gt;): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments. ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;13&lt;/div&gt; significantly changes the impairment model for most financial assets and certain other instruments. ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;13&lt;/div&gt; will require immediate recognition of estimated credit losses expected to occur over the remaining life of many financial assets
 which will generally result in earlier recognition of allowances for credit losses on loans and other financial instruments. ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;13&lt;/div&gt; is effective for the Company's fiscal year beginning &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; March 1

 &lt;/div&gt;the FASB issued ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;02
&lt;/div&gt; Leases (Topic &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;842&lt;/div&gt;)
 which requires the recognition of lease assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet by lessees for those leases currently classified as operating leases under ASC &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;840&lt;/div&gt; &amp;#x201c;Leases.&amp;#x201d; These amendments also require qualitative disclosures along with specific quantitative disclosures. The Company adopted ASU &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2016&lt;/div&gt;-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;02&lt;/div&gt; as of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; March 1
 2019
 &lt;/div&gt;using the modified retrospective method. This method allows the new standard to be applied retrospectively through a cumulative catch-up adjustment recognized upon adoption. As a result
 comparative information in the Company&amp;#x2019;s financial statements has &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; been restated and continues to be reported under the accounting standards in effect for those periods. The Company recorded a Right of Use Asset and Lease Liability on the Consolidated Balance Sheet of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$3.3&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; million upon adoption. The impact of the new standard did &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; affect the Company&amp;#x2019;s cash flows or results of operations. The lease liability reflects the present value of the Company&amp;#x2019;s estimated future minimum lease payments over the lease term
 which includes options that are likely to be exercised

 the Company extends credit to customers
 primarily franchisees that satisfy pre-defined credit criteria. The Company believes that it has limited concentration of credit risk primarily because its receivables are secured by the assets of the franchisees to which the Company ordinarily extends credit
 including
 but &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; limited to
 their franchise rights and inventories. An allowance for doubtful accounts is determined through analysis of the aging of accounts receivable
 assessments of collectability based on historical trends
 and an evaluation of the impact of current and projected economic conditions. The process by which the Company performs its analysis is conducted on a customer by customer
 or franchisee by franchisee
 basis and takes into account
 among other relevant factors
 sales history
 outstanding receivables
 customer financial strength
 as well as customer specific and geographic market factors relevant to projected performance. The Company monitors the collectability of its accounts receivable on an ongoing basis by assessing the credit worthiness of its customers and evaluating the impact of reasonably likely changes in economic conditions that &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;impact credit risks. Estimates with regard to the collectability of accounts receivable are reasonably likely to change in the future. At &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/div&gt; the Company had &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$450
215&lt;/div&gt; of notes receivable outstanding and an allowance for doubtful accounts of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$0&lt;/div&gt; associated with these notes
 compared to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$391
831&lt;/div&gt; of notes receivable outstanding and an allowance for doubtful accounts of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$0&lt;/div&gt; at &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28
 2019. &lt;/div&gt;The notes require monthly payments and bear interest rates ranging from &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;4.5%&lt;/div&gt; to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;6%.&lt;/div&gt; The notes mature through &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; November 2023 &lt;/div&gt;and approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$293
000&lt;/div&gt; of notes receivable are secured by the assets financed. We &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;experience the failure of our wholesale customers
 including our franchisees
 to whom we extend credit to pay amounts owed to us on time
 or at all

  
  
  
  
  


  

  
  


&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020






  
  
  


  
  

  


  


  
  
  
  


  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  


  
  

  


  


  
  
  
  


  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

 2018
 &lt;/div&gt;the Company adopted ASC &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;606.&lt;/div&gt; ASC &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;606&lt;/div&gt; provides that revenues are to be recognized when control of promised goods or services is transferred to a customer in an amount that reflects the consideration expected to be received for those goods or services. This new standard does &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; impact the Company's recognition of revenue from sales of confectionary items to the Company&amp;#x2019;s franchisees and others
 or in its Company-owned stores as those sales are recognized at the time of the underlying sale and are presented net of sales taxes and discounts. The standard also does &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; change the recognition of royalties and marketing fees from franchised or licensed locations
 which are based on a percent of sales and recognized at the time the sales occur. The standard does change the timing in which the Company recognizes initial fees from franchisees and licensees for new franchise locations and renewals that affect the term of the franchise agreement. The Company generally receives a fee associated with the Franchise Agreement or License Agreement (collectively &amp;#x201c;Customer Contracts&amp;#x201d;) at the time that the Customer Contract is entered. These Customer Contracts have a term of up to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;20&lt;/div&gt; years

 License Fees

 2018 &lt;/div&gt;was to recognize initial franchise fees upon new store openings and renewals that impact the term of the franchise agreement upon renewal. In accordance with the new guidance
 the initial franchise services are &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; distinct from the continuing rights or services offered during the term of the franchise agreement
 and will be treated as a single performance obligation. Beginning &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; March 1
 2018
 &lt;/div&gt;initial franchise fees are being recognized as the Company satisfies the performance obligation over the term of the franchise agreement

&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; and &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February 28

 &lt;/div&gt;which was paid on &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; March 13

Note &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19&lt;/div&gt; contains additional information about the Company&amp;#x2019;s suspension of its dividend subsequent to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29

 2014
 &lt;/div&gt;the Company publicly announced a plan to repurchase up to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$3.0&lt;/div&gt; million of its common stock in the open market or in private transactions
 whenever deemed appropriate by management. As of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/div&gt; approximately &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$638

 on &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; December 20
 2019
 &lt;/div&gt;the Company issued Edible a warrant (the &amp;#x201c;Warrant&amp;#x201d;) to purchase up to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;960
677&lt;/div&gt; shares of the Company&amp;#x2019;s common stock (the &amp;#x201c;Warrant Shares&amp;#x201d;) at an exercise price of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$8.76&lt;/div&gt; per share. The Warrant Shares vest in annual tranches in varying amounts following each contract year under the exclusive supplier agreement
 subject to
 and only upon

  
  
  

 2020 &lt;/div&gt;the Board suspended the Company&amp;#x2019;s &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;first&lt;/div&gt; quarter cash dividend payment to preserve cash and provide additional flexibility in the current environment as a result of the economic impact of COVID-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19.&lt;/div&gt; Furthermore

 we have experienced business disruptions resulting from efforts to contain the rapid spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19&lt;/div&gt;)
 including the vast mandated self-quarantines and closures of non-essential business throughout the United States and internationally. Nearly all stores have been directly and negatively impacted by public health measures taken in response to COVID-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19
&lt;/div&gt; with nearly all locations experiencing reduced operations as a result of
 among other things
 modified business hours and store and mall closures. As a result
 franchisees and licensees are &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; ordering products for their stores in line with forecasted amounts. This trend has negatively impacted
 and is expected to continue to negatively impact
 among other things
 factory sales

 our foremost priority is the safety and well-being of our employees
 customers
 franchisees and communities. In addition to our already stringent practices for the quality and safety of our confections
 we are diligently following health and safety guidance issued by the World Health Organization
 the Centers for Disease Control and state and local governmental agencies. COVID-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19&lt;/div&gt; has had an unprecedented impact on our industry as containment measures continue to escalate. Numerous countries
 states and local governments have effected ordinances to protect the public through social distancing
 which has caused
 and we expect will continue to cause
 a significant decrease in
 among other things
 retail traffic and factory sales as a result
 retail sales and royalty and marketing fees. With that said
 Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory products remain available for sale online. Our current focus is on supporting our franchisees and licensees during this challenging time and driving growth in our online sales
 especially in light of our ecommerce licensing agreement with Edible Arrangements&amp;reg;
 LLC (&amp;#x201c;Edible&amp;#x201d;)
 as discussed below

 management is taking all necessary and appropriate action to maximize our liquidity as we navigate the current landscape. These actions include significantly reducing our operating expenses and production volume to reflect reduced sales volumes as well as the elimination of all non-essential spending and capital expenditures. Further
 in an abundance of caution and to maintain ample financial flexibility
 we have drawn down the full amount under our line of credit and we have received a loan under the Paycheck Protection Program (the &amp;#x201c;PPP&amp;#x201d;). The receipt of funds under the PPP has allowed us to avoid workforce reduction measures amidst a steep decline in revenue and production volume. While we believe we have sufficient liquidity with our current cash position
 we will continue to monitor and evaluate all financing alternatives as necessary as these unprecedented events evolve. For more information
 please see Item &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;1A&lt;/div&gt; &amp;#x201c;Risk Factors&amp;#x2014;The Novel Coronavirus (COVID-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19&lt;/div&gt;) Pandemic Has
 and &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; May &lt;/div&gt;Continue to
 Materially and Adversely Affect our Sales
 Earnings

 the Company
 Management and the Board &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;take additional actions as a result of current events related to COVID-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19.&lt;/div&gt; Continued or prolonged disruption to the economy &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;result in
 among other things: an increase in expense associated with obsolete inventory
 an increase in bad debt expense
 expense associated with the impairment of long-lived assets and intangible assets
 an increase in store closures

 2020 (&lt;/div&gt;the &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;first&lt;/div&gt; quarter of FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2021&lt;/div&gt;) and for FY &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2021.&lt;/div&gt; We are unable to reasonably estimate the extent of these decreases. The events
 as described above
 have had a significant impact on our domestic franchisees
 domestic and international licensees and specialty markets customers (collectively &amp;#x201c;Customers&amp;#x201d;). Our ability to realize the full value of our assets depends on the ability of our customers to recover from these events and our business to resume normal operations. Among other financial impacts these events &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;significantly impair our ability to sell inventory on-hand
 collect receivables and realize the value of our tangible and intangible assets. We continue to monitor the situation closely and &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;implement further measures to provide additional financial flexibility as we work to protect our cash position and liquidity. We have determined that the events described above did &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; exist at the balance sheet date and have concluded that they are nonrecognized subsequent events.&amp;nbsp; As a result of this determination &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;no&lt;/div&gt; amounts were recognized as of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; February &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;29

 2020
 &lt;/div&gt;the Company provided notice to the lender to draw down on the line of credit in an amount equal to &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$3.4&lt;/div&gt; million (the full amount of the &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$5.0&lt;/div&gt; million line of credit
 subject to the borrowing base of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;50%&lt;/div&gt; of eligible accounts receivable plus &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;50%&lt;/div&gt; of eligible inventories). On &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; March 16
 2020 &lt;/div&gt;the interest rate for borrowings under the line of credit was &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;3.06%
&lt;/div&gt; which represents the &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;one&lt;/div&gt;-month LIBOR rate plus &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;2.25%.&lt;/div&gt; The outstanding principal balance under the line of credit will be due and payable in full on &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; September 30
 2021. &lt;/div&gt;The Company elected to borrow such amounts to ensure it maintains ample financial flexibility in light of the spread of COVID-&lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;19&lt;/div&gt; and the closures and/or modified hours
 either voluntarily or as a result of governmental orders or quarantines

 2020
 &lt;/div&gt;Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory
 Inc. and U-Swirl International
 Inc. (collectively the &amp;#x201c;Company&amp;#x201d;) entered into Loan Agreements and Promissory Notes (collectively the &amp;#x201c;SBA Loans&amp;#x201d;) with &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;1st&lt;/div&gt; SOURCE BANK pursuant to the Paycheck Protection Program (the &amp;#x201c;PPP&amp;#x201d;) under the recently enacted Coronavirus Aid
 Relief
 and Economic Security Act (&amp;#x201c;CARES Act&amp;#x201d;) administered by the U.S. Small Business Administration. The Company received total proceeds of &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;$1.5&lt;/div&gt; million from the SBA Loans. The SBA Loans are scheduled to mature on &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; April 14 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; April 20
 2022 &lt;/div&gt;and have a &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;1.00%&lt;/div&gt; interest rate and are subject to the terms and conditions applicable to loans administered by the U.S. Small Business Administration under the CARES Act. The SBA Loans &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;be prepaid by the Company at any time prior to maturity with &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;no&lt;/div&gt; prepayment penalties. The SBA Loans contain customary events of default relating to
 among other things
 payment defaults and breaches of representations and warranties. Subject to certain conditions
 the SBA Loans &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;be forgiven in whole or in part by applying for forgiveness pursuant to the CARES Act and the PPP. The amount of loan proceeds eligible for forgiveness is based on a formula based on a number of factors
 including the amount of loan proceeds used by the Company during the &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;eight&lt;/div&gt;-week period after the loan origination for certain purposes
 including payroll costs
 interest on certain mortgage obligations
 rent payments on certain leases
 and certain qualified utility payments
 provided that
 among other things
 at least &lt;div style=display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;&gt;75%&lt;/div&gt; of the loan amount is used for eligible payroll costs
 the employer maintaining or rehiring employees and maintaining salaries at certain levels. In accordance with the requirements of the CARES Act and the PPP







 management is required to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets
 liabilities
 the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities
 at the date of the consolidated financial statements
